It was the Imperial capital of Japan between 740 and 743.]] {{hatnote|This article is about the former town in Kyoto Prefecture, Japan. There is a Japanese city with this name, see [[Kamo, Niigata]]. For other places with this name, see [[Kamo (disambiguation)]].}} {{nihongo|'''Kamo'''|加茂町|Kamo-chō}} was a [[towns of Japan|town]] located in [[Sōraku District, Kyoto|Sōraku District]], [[Kyoto Prefecture|Kyoto]], [[Japan]]. As of February 1, 2007, the town had an estimated [[population]] of 15,907 and a [[population density|density]] of 430.27 persons per km². The total area was 36.97 km². Between the years of 740 to 744, Kamo had been the [[capital of Japan]] named [[Kuni-kyō]]. On March 12, 2007 Kamo was merged with the towns of [[Kizu, Kyoto|Kizu]] and [[Yamashiro, Kyoto|Yamashiro]], all from [[Sōraku District, Kyoto|Sōraku District]], to form the new city of [[Kizugawa, Kyoto|Kizugawa]]. {{commons category|Kamo, Kyoto}} ==External links== *[http://www.town.kamo.kyoto.jp/ Kamo official website] in Japanese [[Category:Dissolved municipalities of Kyoto Prefecture]] {{Kyoto-geo-stub}}
